title: Creates interface with NASA exoplanets API
text: REXoplanets R package provides user-friendly interface NASA’s Exoplanet Archive API. includes functions retrieving analyzing exoplanet data, computing key parameters, classifying celestial bodies, generating visualizations. package emphasizes identifying potentially habitable Earth-like planets. example Shiny application included demonstrate capabilities.

title: Creates interface with NASA exoplanets API
text: recommend using remotes package installation, along system dependencies. remotes available, need set first: Now can install REXoplanets running: , load library, simply run:

title: Creates interface with NASA exoplanets API
text: Fetch data NASA Exoplanet Archive’s TAP service using: Supports filtering replacing column names descriptive labels:
code: fetch_table("[table name]") fetch_table("ps", query_string = "pl_bmasse > 3", pretty_colnames = TRUE)

title: Creates interface with NASA exoplanets API
text: Built-functions habitability Earth similarity analysis, e.g.: calculate_esi() – Earth Similarity Index. calculate_stellar_flux() – Stellar flux based orbital stellar parameters. Quick body classification tools : * classify_planet_type() – Classify planets categories.

title: Creates interface with NASA exoplanets API
text: Generate publication-ready visualizations: scatterplot_esi() – ESI vs. another parameter. plot_star_system() – Stylized star system maps. visualizations return ggplot2 objects easy customization.

title: Creates interface with NASA exoplanets API
text: REXoplanets application provides interactive interface exploring data NASA Exoplanet Archive. allows search star systems, visualize structure, view key information known stellar bodies. run REXoplanets application invoke: start Shiny server open application browser.

what: Calculate the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — calculate_esi
title: Calculate the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — calculate_esi
text: Calculate Earth Similarity Index (ESI)

title: Calculate the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — calculate_esi
Calculate the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — calculate_esi
text: ... number numeric parameters representing planet's characteristics. Parameter names corresponding weight names ending _w (e.g., mass, mass_w). radius_w Numeric. Weight radius. Default 0.57. flux_w Numeric. Weight stellar flux. Default 0.7.

title: Calculate the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — calculate_esi
text: Numeric. Earth Similarity Index (ESI).

title: Calculate the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — calculate_esi
text: function calculates ESI parameter number parameters. default, uses weights 0.57 radius 0.7 stellar flux. ESI (Earth Similarity Index) characterization similar planetary-mass object natural satellite Earth. designed scale zero one, Earth value 1.

title: Calculate the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — calculate_esi
text: Schulze-Makuch, D., Méndez, ., Fairén, . G., von Paris, P., Turse, C., Boyer, G., Davila, . F., Resendes de Sousa António, M., Irwin, L. N., Catling, D. (2011) Two-Tiered Approach Assess Habitability Exoplanets. Astrobiology 11(10): 1041-1052.

title: Calculate the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — calculate_esi
code: # ESI for radius and flux, returns 1 (Earth is perfectly similar to itself) calculate_esi(radius = 1, flux = 1) #> [1] 1 # Mars approximation using radius = 0.532 and flux = 0.43, returns approximately 0.754 calculate_esi(radius = 0.532, flux = 0.43) #> [1] 0.7543736 # Custom 3-parameter ESI (e.g. radius, flux, temperature) calculate_esi(radius = 1.1, flux = 1.2, temp = 288,               radius_w = 0.5, flux_w = 0.3, temp_w = 0.2) #> [1] 0.5922526

title: Calculate star's habitable zone — calculate_star_habitable_zone
text: Calculates star's habitable zone inner outer radius, based star's luminosity.

title: Calculate star's habitable zone — calculate_star_habitable_zone
text: st_lum numeric Stellar luminosity value (log10(L/Lsun) linear). log_lum logical value. TRUE assumes st_lum logarithmic. Defaults TRUE.

title: Calculate star's habitable zone — calculate_star_habitable_zone
text: numeric vector 2 elements first habitable zone inner radius second outer radius.

title: Calculate star's habitable zone — calculate_star_habitable_zone
code: calculate_star_habitable_zone(0) # habitable zone for sun, with logarithmic units #> [1] 0.9534626 1.3736056 calculate_star_habitable_zone(1, log_lum = FALSE) # habitable zone for sun, with linear units #> [1] 0.9534626 1.3736056

title: Calculate stellar flux value — calculate_stellar_flux
text: Calculate stellar flux value

title: Calculate stellar flux value — calculate_stellar_flux
text: st_lum Numeric. Stellar luminosity (log10(L/Lsun) linear). pl_orbsmax Numeric. Orbital distance AU. log_lum Logical. TRUE, assumes st_lum log10(L / Lsun). Defaults TRUE. unit Character. Either "relative" (default) "wm2" convert W/m².

title: Calculate stellar flux value — calculate_stellar_flux
text: Numeric. Stellar flux (relative W/m²).

title: Calculate stellar flux value — calculate_stellar_flux
text: function calculates stellar flux based provided values. assumes luminosity either logarithmic (log10 L/Lsun) linear, optionally converts flux absolute units (W/m²) requested. Stellar flux amount energy star reaches given area per unit time.

title: Calculate stellar flux value — calculate_stellar_flux
code: # Solar-type star, Earth-like orbit calculate_stellar_flux(st_lum = 0, pl_orbsmax = 1) #> [1] 1 # Linear luminosity input (not log), 5x Sun at 2 AU calculate_stellar_flux(st_lum = 5, pl_orbsmax = 2, log_lum = FALSE) #> [1] 1.25 # Output in absolute units (W/m²), Earth-like conditions calculate_stellar_flux(st_lum = 0, pl_orbsmax = 1, unit = "wm2") #> [1] 1361

title: Classify Planet Type — classify_planet_type
text: function returns compact four-character code representing classification exoplanet based mass, equilibrium temperature, orbital eccentricity, density. classification code composed four parts: Mass class: M: Mercury-like planets (< 0.22 Earth masses) E: Earth-like planets (0.22–2.2 Earth masses) S: Super-Earths (2.2–22 Earth masses) N: Neptune-like planets (22–127 Earth masses) J: Jupiter-like giants (127–4450 Earth masses) D: Degenerate-matter/brown dwarf-like objects (>= 4450 Earth masses) Temperature class: F: Frozen (T < 250 K) W: Temperate/water zone (250–450 K) G: Gaseous (450–1000 K) R: Roasters (>= 1000 K) Eccentricity: First decimal digit orbital eccentricity. example, 0.26 → 3 → appended 3. Density-based surface/composition class: g: Gas-dominated (< 0.25 g/cm³) w: Water/ice-rich (0.25–2 g/cm³) t: Terrestrial/rocky (2–6 g/cm³) : Iron-rich (6–13 g/cm³) s: Super-dense (>= 13 g/cm³)

title: Classify Planet Type — classify_planet_type
text: pl_bmasse Numeric. Planetary mass Earth masses. Must > 0. pl_eqt Numeric. Planetary equilibrium temperature Kelvin. Must > 0. pl_orbeccen Numeric. Orbital eccentricity. Must > 0. pl_dens Numeric. Planetary density g/cm³. Must > 0.

title: Classify Planet Type — classify_planet_type
text: character string containing 4-character planet classification code.

title: Classify Planet Type — classify_planet_type
code: classify_planet_type(1.0, 288, 0.0167, 5.5)   # Earth-like: "EW0t" #> [1] "EW0t" classify_planet_type(318, 1300, 0.05, 1.3)    # Hot Jupiter: "JR3w" #> [1] "JR0w" classify_planet_type(0.1, 180, 0.2, 0.1)      # Cold, light, low-density: "MF2g" #> [1] "MF2g"

Fetch Exoplanets table — fetch_table
text: Fetch Exoplanets table

title: Fetch Exoplanets table — fetch_table
code: fetch_table(   table,   query_string = NULL,   pretty_colnames = FALSE,   format = "csv" )

title: Fetch Exoplanets table — fetch_table
text: table string specifying table query. Must one : ps - Planetary Systems table pscomppars – Planetary Systems Composite Parameters table stellarhosts – Stellar Hosts table keplernames – Kepler Confirmed Names query_string Optional ADQL clause string, e.g., pl_bmasse > 1 st_teff < 6000. pretty_colnames Optional bool value. TRUE replaces database column names labels / descriptions. Defaults FALSE. Currently tables ps pscomppars supported. format Optional char value specifying output format. Can either "csv" data frame, "json" named list.

title: Fetch Exoplanets table — fetch_table
text: data frame named list containing fetched data.

title: Fetch Exoplanets table — fetch_table
text: Fetches data exoplanets TAP (Table Access Protocol) service returns data frame named list. can optionally specify ADQL clause filter rows based conditions.

title: Fetch Exoplanets table — fetch_table
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  # All entries from Stellar Hosts table  fetch_table("stellarhosts")  # Entries from Planetary Systems table where planetary mass > 3 times the earth mass  fetch_table("ps", query_string = "pl_bmasse > 3")  # Planets orbiting Teegarden's Star with radius > 1 Earth radius  fetch_table("pscomppars", query_string = "hostname = 'Teegarden''s Star' and pl_rade > 1") } # }

what: Plot a Stylized Star System — plot_star_system
title: Plot a Stylized Star System — plot_star_system
text: Creates stylized polar plot planetary system, displaying planets circular orbits around central star. Planet size scaled radius, orbit position randomized aesthetics, planet color mapped density. star's color optionally based spectral type. Optionally, star's habitable zone visualization can overlayed.

title: Plot a Stylized Star System — plot_star_system
Plot a Stylized Star System — plot_star_system
text: planet_data data frame containing planetary system data. Must include: pl_orbsmax: semi-major axis (orbital distance), pl_rade: planetary radius (Earth radii), pl_dens: planetary density (g/cm³). spectral_type Optional character string indicating star's spectral type. Accepted values: O, B, , F, G, K, M. habitable_zone Optional numeric vector containing 2 values: Inner outer habitable zone edges AU.

title: Plot a Stylized Star System — plot_star_system
text: ggplot2 object representing planetary system visualization.

title: Plot a Stylized Star System — plot_star_system
text: central star positioned origin planets arranged orbits increasing radius. Orbit lines shown gray clarity.

title: Plot a Stylized Star System — plot_star_system
code: # Plot system GJ 682 (with hostid == "2.101289") data = closest_50_exoplanets |>   subset(hostid == 2.101289) spectral_type = classify_star_spectral_type(data$st_teff[1]) plot_star_system(data,                  spectral_type,                  habitable_zone = calculate_star_habitable_zone(data$st_lum[1]))

what: Generate a Scatterplot of the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — scatterplot_esi
title: Generate a Scatterplot of the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — scatterplot_esi
text: Creates log-log scatterplot planetary radius versus stellar flux, colored Earth Similarity Index (ESI).

title: Generate a Scatterplot of the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — scatterplot_esi
Generate a Scatterplot of the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — scatterplot_esi
text: data data frame containing exoplanet data. Must include columns: pl_insol: incident stellar flux (Earth flux units), pl_rade: planetary radius (Earth radii), esi: Earth Similarity Index (numeric). plot_limits numeric vector length 2 specifying lower upper bounds. Default c(0.1, 10).

title: Generate a Scatterplot of the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — scatterplot_esi
text: ggplot2 object representing scatterplot.

title: Generate a Scatterplot of the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — scatterplot_esi
text: Dashed lines (1,1) indicate Earth's reference values stellar flux radius.

title: Generate a Scatterplot of the Earth Similarity Index (ESI) — scatterplot_esi
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ closest_50_exoplanets |>   dplyr::mutate(esi = calculate_esi(pl_rade, pl_insol)) |>   scatterplot_esi() } # }

title: Trim planetary systems table — trim_ps_table
text: Trim planetary systems table

title: Trim planetary systems table — trim_ps_table
text: data data frame planetary systems data.

title: Trim planetary systems table — trim_ps_table
text: data frame containing: objectid - Object ID pl_name – Planet name hostname – Host star name sy_dist – Distance system (parsecs) pl_rade – Planetary radius (Earth radii) pl_bmasse – Planetary mass (Earth masses) pl_orbper – Orbital period (days) pl_orbsmax – Semi-major axis (AU) pl_orbeccen – Orbital eccentricity pl_insol – Incident stellar flux (Earth units) st_teff – Stellar effective temperature (K) st_rad – Stellar radius (Solar radii) st_mass – Stellar mass (Solar masses) st_lum – Stellar luminosity (log10 L/Lsun) pl_eqt – Planetary equilibrium temperature (K) pl_dens – Planetary density discoverymethod – Discovery method disc_year – Year discovery sy_snum – Number stars system sy_pnum – Number planets system

title: Trim planetary systems table — trim_ps_table
text: function takes planetary systems data frame, trims include 20 important columns.
